title: How have employment rates changed?
analysis_commentary: It is estimated that around one quarter of working age adults have one or more long-term conditions, and employment rates for this group are around 60% - typically 10-15% lower than for the general population. Trends in employment in the general population showed a fall between 2007 and 2010, whereas employment of people with LTCs was broadly steady. This resulted in a narrowing of the gap between the two rates (from 15% in 2006 to 11% in 2010). Through 2011 both rates remained similar to 2010 levels. However, from mid-2012 employment in the general population began to increase - a rise not reflected in employment rates for those with long-term conditions. This resulted to an increase in the gap between the rates to 14% at 2013/14 Q3.
